questions.text: Which of the following stains is most appropriate to identify fungal morphology in the tissue section?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain is commonly used to identify fungal organisms in tissue sections. It highlights fungal polysaccharides, which appear magenta under a microscope, making it a critical diagnostic tool in histopathology for suspected fungal infections.

questions.text: A skin biopsy from a patient with scaly erythematous plaques was done. Parakeratosis is suspected. Which of the following is not true about parakeratosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Parakeratosis refers to retention of nuclei by keratinocytes in the horny layer

options.label: B
options.text: It is usually associated with an increased granular cell layer

options.label: C
options.text: It is usually focal in psoriasis

options.label: D
options.text: It is a physiologic phenomenon in the oral mucosa

questions.correct_answer: B. It is usually associated with an increased granular cell layer
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is usually associated with an increased granular cell layer.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parakeratosis is the retention of nuclei in keratinocytes within the stratum corneum. It is a pathologic finding in the skin but physiologic in mucous membranes like the oral cavity. Parakeratosis is associated with absent or reduced granular cell layers and is characteristically seen in conditions like psoriasis, where it is focal and diagnostic.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with multiple skin lesions that include raised, red papules and flat, discolored patches. He also has some areas of linear abrasions caused by scratching. The clinician classifies these lesions into primary and secondary categories. Which of the following is not considered a primary lesion of the skin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Excoriation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary skin lesions are the initial changes in the skin, essential for diagnosing dermatological conditions. Examples include macules, nodules, and pustules. Secondary lesions, such as excoriations , occur due to progression, trauma, or manipulation of primary lesions.
  • ➤ initial changes
  • ➤ excoriations

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of collagen type and its location is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: Type IV collagen - basement membrane zone and perivascular regions

questions.correct_answer: D. Type VII collagen - anchoring filaments
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Type VII collagen - anchoring filaments

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type VII collagen is a major component of anchoring fibrils , not anchoring filaments, and plays a key role in epidermal-dermal adhesion. Understanding the specific types and locations of collagen is crucial for diagnosing connective tissue and blistering disorders.
  • ➤ Type VII collagen is a major component of anchoring fibrils

questions.text: Which of the following cells is not involved in the immune response in the skin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Melanocytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melanocytes do not participate in the immune response of the skin, as their primary function is pigment production. Immune responses in the skin are mediated by Langerhans cells, indeterminate dendritic cells, and keratinocytes , which act to detect, process, and respond to antigens. Understanding the distinct roles of skin cells is essential for diagnosing and managing immune-mediated dermatological conditions.
  • ➤ Melanocytes do not participate in the immune response
  • ➤ Langerhans cells, indeterminate dendritic cells, and keratinocytes

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by her parents, who are concerned about unusual skin lesions that have developed over the past few weeks. The lesions initially appeared as blisters and have since evolved into streaky and whorled hyperpigmented lines, predominantly along the trunk and limbs, as shown in the image. The parents mention that several female relatives on the mother's side have had similar skin findings. Which of the following best describes the distribution pattern of these lesions?
questions.correct_answer: B. Along lines of embryonic development
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Along lines of embryonic development

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Incontinentia pigmenti lesions follow the lines of Blaschko, which represent the embryonic developmental pathways.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a gradual loss of hair primarily over the crown and temples over the past 2 years. He mentions that his father and grandfather had similar patterns of hair loss as they aged. On physical examination, there is noticeable thinning of hair at the crown with a receding hairline forming an "M" shape. There are no signs of scaling, redness, or broken hairs on the scalp. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Androgenetic alopecia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Androgenetic alopecia is the most common form of hair loss, characterized by a gradual, patterned thinning of hair mediated by genetic and hormonal factors. In men, it typically begins at the temples and crown, forming an "M" shape hairline. Treatment options include topical minoxidil, oral finasteride, and hair transplant surgery.

questions.text: What are the most likely causes of non-scarring and scarring alopecia respectively among the given options?

options.label: A
options.text: Frontal fibrosing alopecia and telogen effluvium

options.label: B
options.text: Alopecia areata and frontal fibrosing alopecia

options.label: D
options.text: Lichen plano pilaris and frontal fibrosing alopecia

questions.correct_answer: B. Alopecia areata and frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alopecia areata and frontal fibrosing alopecia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-scarring alopecias, such as alopecia areata, involve temporary hair follicle dysfunction without follicular destruction. In contrast, scarring alopecias like frontal fibrosing alopecia are characterized by permanent follicular destruction and scar formation, leading to irreversible hair loss.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman reports significant hair shedding that began three months after a severe stressful event. She describes diffuse thinning of her hair. Physical examination reveals no evidence of scarring or localized alopecia. The patient is informed that most of her hair follicles are likely in the resting phase of the hair cycle. What is the name of this resting phase?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Telogen phase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The telogen phase is the resting phase of the hair cycle. It is characterized by the cessation of active hair growth, and hair is eventually shed during this phase. Stressful events, illnesses, or hormonal changes can trigger telogen effluvium, leading to increased hair shedding.

questions.text: During a clinical skills session, a medical student notices that a patient with circular areas of patchy hair loss on their scalp also has irregularities on their nails. The student is asked to identify the nail finding most commonly associated with this type of hair loss. Which nail finding would be expected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nail pitting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nail pitting is a common finding in patients with alopecia areata, reflecting the systemic nature of autoimmune conditions that can affect both the skin and its appendages.

questions.text: In the treatment of fungal nail infections, a particular class of antifungal agents known as morpholines is formulated as a nail lacquer. Which of the following drugs belongs to this class and is used in this formulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Amorolfine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amorolfine belongs to the morpholine class and is used as a nail lacquer in the treatment of onychomycosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man visits his primary care physician with complaints of unusual sweat stains on his shirts. He mentions that the sweat stains appear to have a bluish-green hue. He denies any significant odor, excessive sweating, or changes in his overall health. On examination, the affected areas correspond to sites of sweat gland activity, with no signs of infection or inflammation. Which of the following conditions is most likely causing this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chromhidrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromhidrosis is a rare condition involving the secretion of colored sweat, which may result from bacterial pigments such as pyocyanin and pyoverdine produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent eruptions primarily on his face, back, and chest. He describes the lesions as inflamed, red, and occasionally painful. Examination reveals numerous comedones, inflamed papules, pustules, and some nodules. Further history reveals that the patient has tried over-the-counter facial cleansers without improvement. The pathophysiology of this condition involves glands that release their contents by lysing the entire cell membrane. Which of the following best describes the secretion mechanism of these glands?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Holocrine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sebaceous glands use a holocrine mechanism of secretion, wherein entire cells lyse to release their contents. This process contributes to the formation of sebum, a key factor in the pathogenesis of acne.
  • ➤ Sebaceous glands use a holocrine mechanism

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents with persistent redness over his nose and cheeks that worsens after alcohol consumption. He reports that the condition began a few months ago and has been associated with occasional pustules and prominent telangiectasia over the affected areas. On examination, erythema with scattered pustules is noted. He denies a history of systemic symptoms such as joint pain or fever. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acne rosacea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acne rosacea is a chronic skin condition characterized by erythema, flushing, telangiectasia, and inflammatory pustules primarily on the central face. Alcohol consumption is a common trigger.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with intensely itchy lesions on her wrists, lower back. On examination, the lesions are violaceous, flat-topped papules with a polygonal shape. Fine, white, lace-like streaks are visible on the surface of some of the lesions. The patient denies any recent medication use or systemic symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lichen planus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by violaceous, flat-topped papules with Wickham striae. It commonly involves the wrists, lower back, and oral mucosa. Histopathology reveals a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermo-epidermal junction, and treatment includes topical corticosteroids as the first-line therapy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with chronic plaque psoriasis presents for treatment. He has widespread lesions on his trunk and extremities that have not responded adequately to topical therapies. The dermatologist recommends a form of phototherapy due to its efficacy and safety profile. Which of the following is the most likely recommended form of phototherapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Narrowband UVB therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Narrowband UVB therapy is the most widely used phototherapy for psoriasis due to its efficacy, safety, and shorter treatment duration compared to other modalities. It involves exposing the skin to UVB light with a wavelength of 311-312 nm, which reduces keratinocyte proliferation and inflammation.
  • ➤ Narrowband UVB therapy

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a sudden eruption of numerous small, red, raindrop-shaped lesions on his trunk and extremities. The lesions appeared over the past few days and are neither itchy nor painful. The child had a sore throat two weeks ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Guttate psoriasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Guttate psoriasis is characterized by a sudden onset of small, red, scaly, raindrop-shaped lesions on the trunk and extremities, often following a streptococcal infection. Recognizing the association with preceding pharyngitis is key to diagnosis and management. Treatment focuses on controlling skin lesions and addressing the underlying infection.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is being treated for bipolar disorder characterized by episodes of hypomania and depression. Her medical history includes a diagnosis of psoriasis and a previous deep vein thrombosis 11 years ago. She is initiated on pharmacological therapy for mood stabilization. Which of the following medications is most likely to exacerbate her psoriasis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lithium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lithium is associated with the exacerbation of psoriasis. It is crucial to evaluate a patient's dermatological history when selecting mood-stabilizing medications, as alternative treatments like valproate or atypical antipsychotics may be preferred in patients with psoriasis.
  • ➤ Lithium is associated with the exacerbation of psoriasis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with a rash. Examination reveals multiple erythematous oval lesions with a thin collarette of scaling just inside the edge. The lesions are distributed over his upper arms and back and range in size from 1 to 5 cm in diameter. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pityriasis rosea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pityriasis rosea is a self-limiting condition often characterized by a herald patch followed by smaller oval lesions with collarette scaling arranged along skin tension lines. Treatment is typically supportive, as the condition resolves spontaneously in 6–12 weeks.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening, painful blisters and erosions over her upper body, arms, and legs. These lesions have developed over several months and are accompanied by pruritus. On examination, there are tense blisters, some of which are de-roofed, exposing erosions. Her oropharyngeal mucosa is relatively spared. She has a medical history of hypertension and epilepsy, for which she is taking lisinopril, indapamide, and carbamazepine. What finding is most likely on skin biopsy?

options.label: D
options.text: IgG deposition at the dermo-epidermal junction

questions.correct_answer: D. IgG deposition at the dermo-epidermal junction
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) IgG deposition at the dermo-epidermal junction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disease characterized by linear IgG deposition at the dermo-epidermal junction. It typically presents with tense blisters and sparing of mucosal surfaces, distinguishing it from pemphigus vulgaris, which involves intercellular IgG deposition and prominent mucosal involvement. Prompt recognition and treatment are essential to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with scaly, crusted lesions on her face and upper chest. She mentions that the lesions have progressively worsened over the past few months. On examination, the lesions are superficial, erythematous, and do not involve the mucous membranes. A Tzanck smear shows acantholytic cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pemphigus foliaceus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus foliaceus is an autoimmune blistering disease characterized by superficial scaly lesions that spare the mucous membranes. It is caused by autoantibodies targeting desmoglein 1, leading to acantholysis in the subcorneal layer of the epidermis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presents with painful, flaccid bullae on his skin and erosions in his mouth. Some of the bullae have ruptured, leaving behind raw, denuded skin. He reports that the blisters easily break. A Tzanck smear from one of the lesions shows acantholytic cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pemphigus vulgaris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by flaccid bullae , mucosal involvement, and the presence of acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear. It is caused by autoantibodies against desmogleins, leading to the loss of keratinocyte adhesion.
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris
  • ➤ flaccid bullae
  • ➤ acantholytic cells

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with flaccid bullae on her trunk and head, as well as slow-healing erosions. She also reports painful oral erosions that have been recurrent. She recalls a similar episode in the past that required hospitalization. Biopsy and immunofluorescence studies confirm the presence of intraepidermal blisters and autoantibodies. What is the most likely structure targeted in this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Desmoglein 3 of desmosomes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris is caused by autoantibodies targeting Desmoglein 3, a desmosomal protein critical for keratinocyte adhesion. It presents with flaccid bullae, erosions, and painful oral lesions. Hemidesmosomes, which are affected in other blistering diseases like bullous pemphigoid, are not involved in pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a chronic, itchy rash on their elbows and knees, which is suspected to be dermatitis herpetiformis. A skin biopsy with direct immunofluorescence is performed. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be found in the dermis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IgA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dermatitis herpetiformis is caused by granular IgA deposition in the dermal papillae , which is a key diagnostic feature on direct immunofluorescence. This condition is strongly associated with gluten sensitivity and celiac disease, and treatment includes a gluten-free diet along with dapsone for symptom control.
  • ➤ granular IgA deposition in the dermal papillae

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman presents with tense, pruritic blisters on her inner thighs and upper arms. A skin biopsy is performed, and direct immunofluorescence is conducted. What is the most likely finding on immunofluorescence?

options.label: A
options.text: IgG and C3 at the dermoepidermal junction

options.label: B
options.text: Granular IgA along the Dermal papillae

options.label: C
options.text: Linear IgA deposits at the dermoepidermal junction

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of fibrinogen at the basement membrane

questions.correct_answer: A. IgG and C3 at the dermoepidermal junction
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IgG and C3 at the dermoepidermal junction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disease characterized by linear deposition of IgG and C3 along the dermoepidermal junction, representing antibodies targeting hemidesmosomal proteins. Treatment includes systemic corticosteroids and immunosuppressive agents.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man diagnosed with leprosy undergoes a lepromin test. The test involves the intradermal injection of antigens derived from Mycobacterium leprae. The result reveals minimal induration and erythema at the injection site. Which of the following statements about the lepromin test is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: The lepromin test measures the cellular immune response to Mycobacterium leprae

options.label: B
options.text: The lepromin test helps differentiate between lepromatous and tuberculoid leprosy

options.label: C
options.text: The lepromin test determines the type of leprosy

options.label: D
options.text: It is a delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) skin test

questions.correct_answer: C. The lepromin test determines the type of leprosy
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The lepromin test determines the type of leprosy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lepromin test assesses the cell-mediated immune response to Mycobacterium leprae. It helps differentiate between tuberculoid and lepromatous leprosy but is not diagnostic and does not determine the specific type of leprosy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with a history of leprosy for which he has been on long-term multidrug therapy. He complains of gradually darkening skin and thickening of the skin that has developed over the past few months. He denies any new medications or other changes in his health. Physical examination reveals hyperpigmentation and ichthyosis-like scaling, predominantly on his extremities. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these side effects?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clofazimine is associated with skin pigmentation changes and ichthyosis-like skin reactions, particularly with long-term use in patients treated for leprosy.

questions.text: Which among the following is correct regarding the healing of leprosy if left untreated?

options.label: B
options.text: Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure

options.label: C
options.text: Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults

options.label: D
options.text: Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid leprosy

questions.correct_answer: D. Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid leprosy
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Indeterminate leprosy has more spontaneous remission than tuberculoid leprosy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of indeterminate leprosy , the disease often resolves spontaneously, with a remission rate as high as 95%. This type of leprosy is more likely to remit compared to tuberculoid leprosy.
  • ➤ indeterminate leprosy

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman, currently undergoing treatment for leprosy with multidrug therapy (MDT), presents with erythema nodosum leprosum (type 2 lepra reaction), which is characterized by painful nodules and systemic symptoms. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Continue MDT & add steroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a pregnant patient with leprosy presenting with a type 2 lepra reaction (erythema nodosum leprosum) , the appropriate management involves continuing MDT and adding systemic corticosteroids to control the immune-mediated reaction. Thalidomide should be avoided due to its teratogenic effects.
  • ➤ type 2 lepra reaction (erythema nodosum leprosum)
  • ➤ continuing MDT
  • ➤ systemic corticosteroids

questions.text: Which nerve is commonly biopsied to diagnose neuritic leprosy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radial cutaneous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The radial cutaneous nerve is often biopsied in cases of pure neuritic leprosy because it is a sensory nerve, minimizing the risk of motor dysfunction while providing adequate tissue for diagnostic purposes.
  • ➤ radial cutaneous nerve
  • ➤ pure neuritic leprosy

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with discoloration of her fingernails, which have turned green over the past two weeks. She works as a dishwasher and frequently immerses her hands in water. Examination reveals greenish discoloration of the nails, separation of the nail plate from the nail bed (onycholysis), and mild thickening of the affected nails. There is no significant pain or swelling. Which of the following bacteria is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Green nail syndrome (chloronychia) is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and is characterized by greenish discoloration of the nail, often associated with onycholysis. Prolonged exposure to moist environments increases the risk, and treatment includes antibiotics and proper nail care.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with multiple crusted lesions on his face, particularly around his mouth and nose. The mother reports that the lesions started as small red bumps that later developed into blisters and ruptured, leaving a crust. Examination reveals honey-colored crusts over erythematous skin. The child is afebrile and otherwise well. Which of the following bacterial skin infections is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Non-bullous impetigo

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-bullous impetigo is a superficial bacterial skin infection, commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes, and is characterized by honey-colored crusts. These crusts result from dried exudate and are the hallmark of the condition. Treatment includes topical or oral antibiotics depending on the severity of the infection.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with a rash in the groin area that has been present for the past three months. He reports no itching, pain, or systemic symptoms. On examination, the rash is bilateral and symmetrical, consisting of well-demarcated pink to brown patches with fine scaling and superficial fissures. The lesions fluoresce coral-red under Wood's lamp examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Erythrasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythrasma is a bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum and is characterized by asymptomatic, well-demarcated pink to brown patches in intertriginous areas. The hallmark diagnostic feature is coral-red fluorescence under Wood's lamp. Treatment typically involves topical or systemic antibiotics, such as clindamycin or erythromycin.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man has a known history of cutaneous tuberculosis. On diascopy, the skin lesion exhibits a translucent appearance. What is the most likely structure identified during diascopy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Apple jelly nodules

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Apple jelly nodules, seen on diascopy, are a hallmark feature of cutaneous tuberculosis (e.g., lupus vulgaris). They appear as translucent yellowish-brown lesions due to granulomatous inflammation in the dermis. This finding is diagnostic in conditions like lupus vulgaris and distinguishes it from other dermatoses.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with multiple asymptomatic, pinpoint papules on the dorsum of his arms and forearms, as well as the shaft of his penis. He denies any itching or pain. Physical examination reveals smooth, flat-topped, flesh-colored papules. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lichen nitidus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lichen nitidus is a benign condition that presents with asymptomatic, small, flesh-colored papules typically on the arms, chest, and genitalia. It is commonly seen in children and young adults and usually resolves spontaneously without the need for treatment.
  • ➤ Lichen nitidus

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a chronic, ulcerated lesion over her left supraclavicular area. She reports a history of prolonged low-grade fever, night sweats, and weight loss. On physical examination, there is a thickened, indurated plaque with multiple sinus tracts and seropurulent discharge. Enlarged matted lymph nodes are palpated in the cervical region. The patient has a history of tuberculosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Scrofuloderma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scrofuloderma is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis caused by direct extension of infection from underlying lymph nodes, bones, or joints to the overlying skin. It presents with chronic ulceration, sinus tract formation, and matted lymphadenopathy, particularly in patients with a history of tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with fever, irritability, and refusal to eat for the past three days. On examination, he has multiple painful ulcers and blisters on his gums and oral mucosa. His parents report that he has had similar symptoms in the past but less severe. What is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Herpes simplex virus (HSV)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpetic gingivostomatitis , caused by HSV-1, is the most common cause of gingivostomatitis in children. It presents with painful oral ulcers, swollen gums, and fever. Management includes supportive care and antiviral therapy in severe cases.
  • ➤ Herpetic gingivostomatitis

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with multiple lesions on his lower abdomen, which have progressively increased in number over the past six weeks. Initially, there was only one lesion, but now approximately 10 are visible. On examination, the lesions are raised, 1–2 mm in diameter, and have a characteristic umbilicated appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Molluscum contagiosum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by umbilicated papules caused by a poxvirus. It is commonly seen in immunocompetent individuals but may present more extensively in immunocompromised patients. Diagnosis is clinical, and treatment may include cryotherapy, curettage, or topical agents for cosmetic or symptomatic relief.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with severe, unilateral, burning pain and erythema on the right flank, followed by the appearance of clear fluid-filled vesicles in a dermatomal distribution. His physician performs a scraping of the base of a fresh vesicle for cytological examination. What is the most likely finding on microscopic examination?

options.label: B
options.text: Neutrophilic infiltrate to exclude bacterial superinfection

options.label: C
options.text: Eosinophilic infiltrate to diagnose an insect bite

options.label: D
options.text: Acantholytic cells to diagnose an autoimmune blistering disease

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A modified keratinocyte

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Herpes Zoster, the Tzanck smear is a diagnostic tool used to detect cytopathic changes caused by the varicella-zoster virus. Findings include Tzanck cells (modified keratinocytes) with Cowdry type I and II inclusions. This test helps confirm the diagnosis of viral infections like Herpes Zoster and Herpes Simplex.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with patchy hair loss and scaling on the scalp. The child also has itching and mild inflammation in the affected areas. Wood's lamp examination reveals bright green fluorescence of the hair. Fungal culture is performed to identify the causative organism. Which of the following is the most likely organism isolated on fungal culture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Microsporum canis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinea capitis caused by Microsporum species produces a bright green fluorescence under a Wood's lamp due to pteridine residues. This diagnostic feature helps differentiate Microsporum infections from those caused by Trichophyton species, which generally do not fluoresce.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with an itchy, circular rash in his groin area that has been gradually worsening over the past two weeks. He describes the rash as scaly, red, and having a raised border with a central clearing. He has a history of frequent gym visits and uses communal showers. On examination, the rash is erythematous with a well-demarcated border and fine scaling. There is no systemic involvement. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinea cruris , caused by Trichophyton rubrum, is a dermatophyte infection of the groin characterized by an erythematous, scaly rash with a well-defined border and central clearing. It thrives in warm, moist environments and is common in individuals with excessive sweating or those who use communal facilities. Treatment includes topical or oral antifungal agents.
  • ➤ Tinea cruris

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately differentiates eumycotic mycetoma from actinomycotic mycetoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Eumycotic mycetoma is caused by fungal pathogens, while actinomycotic mycetoma is caused by bacterial pathogens

options.label: B
options.text: Eumycotic mycetoma is characterized by the formation of grains, while actinomycotic mycetoma is not

options.label: C
options.text: Eumycotic mycetoma is predominantly a subcutaneous infection, while actinomycotic mycetoma affects deep tissues and organs

options.label: D
options.text: Eumycotic mycetoma responds well to antibiotic therapy, while actinomycotic mycetoma requires antifungal treatment

questions.correct_answer: A. Eumycotic mycetoma is caused by fungal pathogens, while actinomycotic mycetoma is caused by bacterial pathogens
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Eumycotic mycetoma is caused by fungal pathogens, while actinomycotic mycetoma is caused by bacterial pathogens.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eumycotic mycetoma is caused by fungal pathogens (e.g., Madurella and Exophiala), while actinomycotic mycetoma is caused by bacterial pathogens (e.g., Actinomyces and Nocardia). Differentiation is crucial, as antifungal therapy is required for eumycotic mycetoma, whereas actinomycotic mycetoma responds to prolonged antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with intense itching in the pubic region for the past two weeks. Examination reveals small, bluish macules (maculae ceruleae) on the inner thighs and several small insects adhering to the base of pubic hair. The patient confirms recent sexual activity but denies any other symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1% permethrin (topical lotion)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 1% permethrin topical lotion is the first-line treatment for pediculosis pubis. It paralyzes and kills lice and their eggs, offering a high cure rate and minimal side effects. Simultaneous treatment of sexual partners and washing infested items in hot water are essential to prevent reinfection.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of advanced HIV infection presents with thickened, plaques on his hands, feet, and scalp. He resides in a long-term care facility, where several other residents have reported pruritic skin rashes. Examination reveals hyperkeratotic lesions with visible scales and minimal itching. Microscopy of skin scrapings reveals an extensive mite burden. Which of the following types of scabies is most likely responsible for the outbreak?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crusted scabies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crusted scabies is a severe, highly contagious form of scabies with an overwhelming mite burden. It is commonly associated with immunocompromised individuals and institutional outbreaks. Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment with topical and systemic scabicides are essential to control the spread and manage symptoms effectively.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his genital region, which he noticed two weeks ago. On examination, the ulcer is firm, round, and indurated with a raised border. He denies any other symptoms such as fever, discharge, or pain. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the described lesion, including the presence of the "button sign"?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Primary syphilis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "button sign," characterized by a firm, indurated texture of the ulcer, is a hallmark feature of the painless chancre seen in primary syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection caused by Treponema pallidum.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male presents with a painful inguinal swelling and a history of unprotected sexual encounters. Examination reveals a large, tender lymph node. Which of the following sexually transmitted infections is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lymphogranuloma venereum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lymphogranuloma venereum is characterized by the development of buboes, which are painful, swollen lymph nodes, following a genital ulcer in the context of a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, or L3.

questions.text: A 30-year-old sexually active male presents with a malodorous, ulcerative lesion on the glans penis. The lesion has a beefy red granulation tissue without any associated inguinal lymphadenopathy. He reports multiple unprotected sexual encounters but denies any systemic symptoms. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Calymmatobacterium granulomatis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Granuloma inguinale (donovanosis), caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, presents with painless, progressive ulcerative lesions with vibrant red granulation tissue and no associated lymphadenopathy. This differentiates it from other sexually transmitted infections like syphilis and herpes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is treated for early latent syphilis with intramuscular penicillin. Fourteen hours after receiving the injection, she develops a high-grade fever, generalized myalgia, and severe bone pain. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction occurs within 24 hours of penicillin therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Penicillin cannot be used in future

questions.correct_answer: B. Penicillin cannot be used in future
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Penicillin cannot be used in future

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a transient, self-limited inflammatory response occurring within 24 hours of antibiotic treatment for spirochetal infections like syphilis. It is triggered by the release of lipoproteins from lysed spirochetes and presents with fever, myalgia, and other systemic symptoms. It does not contraindicate the use of penicillin for future treatment.

questions.text: A 33-year-old individual presents with painless, beefy-red, ulcerative lesions on the genitalia. The lesions have a granular appearance, a friable base, and bleed easily when manipulated. The patient also reports swelling in the groin area. Microscopic examination of a tissue sample reveals intracellular, rod-shaped organisms known as Donovan bodies. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Granuloma inguinale

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Granuloma inguinale (Donovanosis) is a chronic sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It is characterized by painless, beefy-red, ulcerative lesions with a friable base and the presence of Donovan bodies (intracellular rod-shaped bacteria) on microscopy. Diagnosis is confirmed through microscopic examination, and treatment involves antibiotics such as azithromycin.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with multiple raised, pinkish-gray, cauliflower-like growths around the perianal region. The lesions have been progressively increasing in size over the past three months. He denies pain but reports occasional mild itching. Physical examination reveals multiple pedunculated lesions localized to the perianal area, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Condyloma acuminata

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Condyloma acuminata are genital warts caused by HPV, commonly types 6 and 11. They present as pedunculated, cauliflower-like lesions and are highly associated with HPV infection. Treatment focuses on lesion removal and reducing transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is correctly correlated with its incubation period?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Syphilis – 90 days

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with painless lesions in the genital area. The patient reports a history of unprotected sexual contact several months ago. On examination, there are multiple, broad-based, moist, flat-topped papules in the perineal region, as shown in the image. A blood test for Treponema pallidum is positive. What is the most likely stage of syphilis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Secondary syphilis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Condyloma lata are highly infectious, broad, moist, flat-topped papules characteristic of secondary syphilis. This stage occurs weeks to months after the initial Treponema pallidum infection and may also present with systemic symptoms such as rash, lymphadenopathy, and mucosal lesions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with multiple painless, skin-colored growths on the genital area. She is diagnosed with genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). Which of the following is the treatment of choice in her case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cryotherapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cryotherapy is the treatment of choice for genital warts in pregnancy, as it is safe and effective. Other therapies, such as podophyllotoxins and imiquimod are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their potential teratogenic effects.

questions.text: Match the Genital ulcer disease in Colum A with its clinical presentation in Colum B
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a suspected diagnosis of contact dermatitis is referred for patch testing to confirm the allergen responsible for her symptoms. She has been instructed to discontinue steroids and immunosuppressants before testing, ensure her disease is controlled, and avoid active lesions at the test site. After the patch is applied, what is the optimal time schedule to read the results?

options.label: C
options.text: 72 hours after patch application as a single reading

options.label: D
options.text: Call the person in the evening after a morning application and in the morning after an evening application

questions.correct_answer: B. 48 and 96 hours after patch application
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 48 and 96 hours after patch application

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patch testing is a diagnostic method for identifying contact allergens. The test results should be read at 48 hours (initial reactions) and 96 hours (delayed reactions). This dual schedule ensures accurate detection of allergens and avoids missing late hypersensitivity responses.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent episodes of itchy, red skin lesions on his arms and face, wheezing during physical activity, and frequent sneezing with a runny nose, especially during the spring season. The clinician discusses the concept of the atopic triad with the parents. Which of the following is not part of the classic atopic triad?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Urticaria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The atopic triad consists of eczema, allergic rhinitis, and asthma, conditions that share a common atopic predisposition and often coexist. Urticaria is not part of this triad, although it is an allergic condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with an itchy, scaly rash that has gradually progressed over the past few months. Examination reveals ill-defined, pink-colored patches with a yellow-brown scale located on the sternum, eyebrows, and nasal bridge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Seborrhoeic dermatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Seborrhoeic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition affecting sebaceous gland-rich areas, characterized by pink, scaly patches with yellow-brown greasy scales. Treatment includes antifungals and mild topical corticosteroids for symptom relief.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with bluish-black discoloration on her cheeks and forehead, which she noticed progressively worsening over the last few years. She has been using a hydroquinone-containing cream for hyperpigmentation for over five years. Examination reveals irregular pigmentation primarily in sun-exposed areas with no evidence of erythema or scaling. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for her findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ochronosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ochronosis is a condition characterized by bluish-black or brownish-black pigmentation of the skin caused by prolonged use of hydroquinone-containing products. Prevention by limiting hydroquinone use is key, as treatment options for ochronosis are limited and the condition is difficult to reverse.
  • ➤ Ochronosis

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with dark, irregular patches on her cheeks and forehead that have progressively worsened over the last six months. She reports that the pigmentation is more pronounced after sun exposure. The patient has tried over-the-counter skin-lightening creams with minimal improvement. Which of the following treatment modalities is least likely to be used as a primary management option for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Topical corticosteroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Topical corticosteroids are not typically used alone as a primary treatment for melasma. The management of melasma focuses on depigmenting agents like hydroquinone, exfoliation through chemical peels, and advanced therapies such as laser treatment. Sun protection is critical to prevent worsening of the condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with patches of depigmented skin on the dorsum of both hands that have developed over the past few weeks. She has attempted treatment with emollients and topical hydrocortisone without improvement. On examination, the patches are well-demarcated and devoid of pigmentation. Her medical history is significant for thyrotoxicosis, which is managed with carbimazole and thyroxine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitiligo

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitiligo is an acquired autoimmune condition leading to symmetric, depigmented patches and is associated with other autoimmune diseases like thyroid dysfunction. It is distinguished from other causes of hypopigmentation by its progressive nature and autoimmune basis. Piebaldism is congenital and presents with stable depigmentation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with recurrent skin eruptions on his arms and legs. He reports a history of frequent Herpes simplex virus infections. On examination, there are multiple target lesions characterized by a central dusky zone surrounded by concentric rings of erythema. The patient denies systemic symptoms such as fever or malaise. Based on the clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Erythema Multiforme (EMF)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythema Multiforme is an acute hypersensitivity reaction often triggered by Herpes simplex virus infection. It is characterized by target lesions with a central dusky zone and concentric rings of erythema, typically affecting the extremities. Early recognition is crucial to differentiate it from more severe conditions such as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male develops a sharply demarcated red-brown lesion on his lips following treatment for amoebic dysentery. He reports a burning sensation at the site of the lesion. The lesion resolves but reappears at the same location after re-exposure to the same medication. Which of the following is the most likely skin reaction caused by the drug used in his treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fixed drug eruption

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fixed drug eruption is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction characterized by the appearance of sharply demarcated lesions that recur at the same location upon re-exposure to the offending drug. Common culprits include metronidazole, NSAIDs, tetracyclines, and paracetamol.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of skin changes over the past few months. She reports tightening of the skin on her hands and face, as well as discoloration on her neck and back. On further questioning, she admits to episodes of Raynaud’s phenomenon during cold weather. Examination reveals the skin pattern shown in the image below, which includes scattered hypopigmented patches interspersed with normal pigmentation. What is this skin manifestation shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Salt and pepper pigmentation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Salt and pepper pigmentation is a distinctive skin manifestation of systemic sclerosis . It presents as mottled hypopigmented and pigmented areas, typically in sun-exposed regions, and is commonly associated with Raynaud’s phenomenon and other systemic features of the disease.
  • ➤ systemic sclerosis
  • ➤ Raynaud’s phenomenon

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. The mother reports that a raised, bright red lesion on the infant’s forearm, which had been present since birth, is now becoming less prominent. Examination reveals a faint pink patch with residual fine, dilated blood vessels on the site where the lesion was previously located. Which of the following pediatric dermatoses is most likely characterized by these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Infantile hemangiomas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infantile hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors that undergo a characteristic growth and regression cycle. Telangiectasias, or fine dilated blood vessels, may persist as a remnant after involution of the hemangioma. While most cases resolve spontaneously, complications may necessitate treatment with beta-blockers or laser therapy.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with a history of severe sunburn after minimal sun exposure. The patient reports freckling in sun-exposed areas, dry skin, and changes in skin pigmentation. Examination reveals patches of hyperpigmented skin, as well as xerotic changes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Xeroderma pigmentosum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Xeroderma pigmentosum is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defects in nucleotide excision repair mechanisms, leading to extreme photosensitivity, pigmentary abnormalities, and a significantly increased risk of skin cancer. Early diagnosis and strict UV protection are critical to reduce complications.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with multiple soft, pea-sized bumps on the skin that exhibit a positive buttonhole sign. The child also has some pigmentary lesions on the body. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ash leaf macule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) presents with neurofibromas, café-au-lait macules, and Lisch nodules, and follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. Ash leaf macules are not associated with NF1; they are characteristic of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic due to a rash that has progressively worsened over the past few weeks. The parents report that the rash primarily affects the hands, feet, and areas around the mouth and anus. The infant also has frequent watery stools and has not been gaining weight as expected. Examination reveals erythematous, scaly lesions in the periorificial regions and extremities. Laboratory investigations show low serum zinc levels. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the infant's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acrodermatitis enteropathica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by impaired zinc absorption. It manifests in infancy with dermatitis (erythematous, scaly lesions in periorificial and extremity areas), diarrhea, and failure to thrive. Low serum zinc levels confirm the diagnosis, and lifelong zinc supplementation is the cornerstone of treatment.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with bilateral, symmetrical erythematous lesions over her shins. The lesions have a firm consistency and an orange-peel texture on examination. She denies any history of pain, ulceration, or recent trauma. Laboratory findings include normal inflammatory markers and no systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pretibial myxedema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pretibial myxedema is a hallmark feature of Graves' disease and presents as symmetrical, non-pitting, orange-peel textured lesions over the shins

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presents with widespread erythema and pustular eruptions over her body. She has a known history of psoriasis and reports being recently prescribed oral corticosteroids for the management of an acute respiratory condition. Her vital signs are stable. Laboratory findings are awaited. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Admission to the hospital

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Generalized pustular psoriasis is a dermatological emergency that requires prompt hospitalization for supportive care and initiation of specific treatment. Systemic corticosteroid withdrawal is a major precipitant of this condition.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with diffuse erythroderma, severe pruritus, and generalized lymphadenopathy. A skin biopsy reveals the presence of atypical T lymphocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mycosis fungoides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mycosis fungoides is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by atypical T lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei infiltrating the skin. It can present with patchy, plaque-like lesions or erythroderma in advanced stages. Skin biopsy findings of atypical lymphocytes and diffuse erythroderma are key diagnostic features.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman undergoes excision of a pigmented lesion from her thigh, which is confirmed on histology to be a malignant melanoma. Which of the following is the most significant factor in determining her prognosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Number of sunburn episodes before the age of 18 years

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Depth of melanoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The depth of melanoma (Breslow thickness) is the most critical prognostic factor for malignant melanoma, guiding staging and management decisions. It reflects the likelihood of metastasis and overall survival, underscoring its importance in clinical practice.
  • ➤ depth of melanoma (Breslow thickness)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a hard, conical projection on his forearm that resembles an animal's horn. The lesion has been gradually increasing in size, is painful, and shows redness and induration at the base. He has a history of chronic sun exposure. Based on these findings, which of the following skin cancers is most commonly associated with this lesion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A cutaneous horn is a hyperkeratotic lesion that may arise from benign, premalignant, or malignant skin conditions. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common malignancy associated with cutaneous horns, especially in cases involving sun-exposed areas, pain, redness, induration, or a wide base.
  • ➤ cutaneous horn
  • ➤ Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately differentiates keloids from hypertrophic scars?

options.label: A
options.text: Keloids are more common in individuals with darker skin tones

options.label: B
options.text: Hypertrophic scars extend beyond the boundaries of the original wound

options.label: C
options.text: Keloids are primarily composed of collagen type I

options.label: D
options.text: Keloids occur exclusively in response to traumatic wounds

questions.correct_answer: A. Keloids are more common in individuals with darker skin tones
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Keloids are more common in individuals with darker skin tones

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keloids are characterized by excessive fibrous tissue growth that extends beyond the original wound and are more common in individuals with darker skin tones. They predominantly consist of collagen type III and may arise from various types of skin injuries, including minor trauma. Hypertrophic scars, in contrast, remain confined within the wound boundaries.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to multiple small, flat, hypopigmented macules on her trunk and extremities following Blaschko lines. The lesions resemble "scattered paint splatters." On further evaluation, the child is found to have dental abnormalities, including missing or malformed teeth, and intellectual disability. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Incontinentia pigmenti

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Incontinentia pigmenti is a rare X-linked genodermatosis characterized by hypopigmented macules resembling "scattered paint splatters," as well as dental, neurological, and ophthalmic abnormalities. It progresses through four distinct stages of skin lesions and primarily affects females.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a rapidly progressive lesion over her shin. The lesion started as a small, red papule and subsequently developed into a deep, necrotic ulcer with a violaceous border. She denies recent trauma to the area. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pyoderma gangrenosum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyoderma gangrenosum is a neutrophilic dermatosis presenting as rapidly progressive ulcers with undermined edges and violaceous borders. It is associated with systemic conditions, including inflammatory bowel disease, and requires immunosuppressive therapy for management. Early recognition is essential to prevent unnecessary surgical debridement, which can exacerbate the condition due to pathergy.
